title: Stardust
descriptions:
In the English village of Wall, named for the ancient stone barrier that borders it, young Tristan Thorn longs to prove himself worthy of the aloof Victoria. When a falling star streaks beyond the wall into the magical kingdom of Stormhold, Tristan vows to retrieve it as a token of his love. With the help of a hidden gap and a mysterious pass, he crosses into Stormhold, a realm where magic is real and danger is constant.

The fallen “star” turns out to be a woman named Yvaine, transformed into human form upon crashing to earth. She is luminous, sardonic, and none too pleased about being hauled across a strange land by an earnest shop boy. Tristan, stubborn yet kindhearted, binds her to him with a magical chain, promising to take her back to Victoria. Their uneasy alliance becomes the heart of a quest that soon entangles them in a web of competing factions.

The dying king of Stormhold has cast his ruby necklace into the sky, decreeing that whichever of his surviving sons retrieves it will become his heir. The gem’s impact knocked Yvaine from the heavens, and its restoration to the necklace will decide the succession. The king’s remaining sons—primarily the ruthless Septimus—hunt the stone and anyone connected to it, trailing bodies and bickering ghosts. Meanwhile, a trio of ancient witches led by the formidable Lamia sense the star’s fall. Consuming a star’s heart will restore their youth and power, and so Lamia rejuvenates herself with the last of their dwindling magic and sets out, determined to carve Yvaine’s heart from her chest.

Tristan and Yvaine journey through Stormhold’s enchanted landscapes: wild forests, inns where illusions lure travelers, and airship-laden skies. They are aided by Captain Shakespeare, the flamboyant and secretly tender-hearted captain of the lightning-harvesting skyship Caspartine. While posing as a fearsome rogue to his crew, Shakespeare recognizes Tristan and Yvaine’s plight and shelters them, teaching Tristan swordplay, confidence, and how to dress like a gentleman. In the close quarters of the ship, Tristan and Yvaine’s initial antagonism softens into affection. Yvaine confesses that stars can love, and when they do, they shine brighter; Tristan, torn between his promise to Victoria and his growing feelings, is slow to understand the depth of that declaration.

After disembarking, Tristan seeks to resolve his original promise. He arranges to present Yvaine to Victoria, planning to keep his word, but complications arise. Yvaine, who cannot cross the wall without dying now that she has fallen in love, follows him toward the border unaware of the danger. Lamia’s spells tighten around them, and Septimus closes in, using necromancy and cold calculation to track the ruby and the star.

The convergence happens at the witches’ lair, an eerie, crumbling manor where Lamia and her sisters set elaborate traps. Tristan rescues Yvaine from an enchanted coach, but the pair are drawn into a final showdown inside the manor’s hall. Septimus arrives to claim the necklace and fights with grim efficiency. Lamia, revealing her full power, manipulates the environment—shattering glass, conjuring fire, and animating metal. Septimus and Tristan duel; the prince is ultimately killed through Lamia’s sorcery, leaving the succession unresolved. The ghosts of his brothers, who have been morbidly commenting on events, watch keenly.

At the climax, Lamia attempts to cut out Yvaine’s heart. Tristan appears overmatched until he realizes that Yvaine’s love is her greatest power. Encouraged, Yvaine unleashes a brilliant stellar light that incinerates Lamia’s illusions and destroys her remaining sisters. Lamia, momentarily showing grief and emptiness, tries one last trick but falters when she recognizes that her victory would leave her alone again. Still, her malice returns, and Yvaine’s light finally ends her threat. With the witches gone, the manor collapses into ruin.

Tristan discovers he is the son of Una, the king’s long-lost daughter who was enslaved years ago by a witch. Freed at last, Una reveals Tristan’s true heritage: he is a prince of Stormhold, making him the rightful heir now that the other contenders are dead. The ruby necklace, reclaimed, confirms his claim.

Tristan and Yvaine return to Wall one last time. He faces Victoria and, in a gentle but firm reversal, rejects her fickle affections; she, having been impressed by Tristan’s transformation and the allure of adventure, is left to reckon with her earlier disdain. Tristan realizes that his love for Yvaine is real and reciprocated. They cross back into Stormhold, where Tristan is crowned king with Yvaine at his side.

As rulers, Tristan and Yvaine bring a golden era
